metadata.titleEn: DSM product data set of Tibet Bomi resource 3 satellite image (2018)
metadata.description:
The data is the large-scale DSM data of debris flow gully area generated by using the purchased resource No. 3 satellite remote sensing image of the demonstration area and based on the stereo image pair matching method. The processing method is as follows:
(1) Due to the large amount of cloud and shadow noise in the original image, this study uses IDL language to develop and form a special denoising and information completion program for satellite images in cloudy mountainous areas.
(2) The emmetropia correction image is used as the left image and the front view correction image is the right image. Envi is used for DSM production.
(3) Using aster-dem data with 30 m resolution, at least 4 typical ground control points are selected for geographic correction to ensure that the geographic coordinate error is in the order of 1 ".
(4) Cross entropy, root mean square error and area error information entropy are used as accuracy evaluation indexes. Compared with the DSM obtained from the original data, it is verified that the imaging accuracy of the processed DSM is improved.
metadata.instructions:
The data is stored as grid data in GeoTIFF format. The file name is dsm20181029 TIF, 604mb in size. When using the data of "Tibet Bomi resources No. 3 satellite image DSM product data set (2018)", the following papers shall be cited:
[1] Peng S, Huang F, Tie B, et al. Optimization research on DSM product generation of ZY-3 satellite image based on the combination of image frequency-domain fusion and filtering.  IGARSS, 2020: 244-247.

background: Regional climatic conditions are a primary determinant of agricultural productivity. Changes in temperature and precipitation will result in changes in land and water regimes that may subsequently affect agricultural productivity. Over the past century, China has experienced substantial climate change: during the past 100 years, the annual average temperature has increased by 0.5–0.8 °C and the distribution of precipitation has become more uneven. Agriculture in China is a major industry, supporting over 20% of the world’s population with only 8% of global cultivated area, and it is also a major importer of feed grains in the world market. Climatic-gridded datasets, generated from the interpolation of observations, express the distribution of climate over space, and they are widely used in global and regional climate change research. Air temperature and precipitation are the most important basic elements in climatic research. Commonly used global monthly climatic datasets, such as those with 0.5° resolution produced by the Climatic Research Unit (CRU) of the University of East Anglia in the UK, and by the Climate Prediction Centre (CPC) released by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), have been used to analyze the modern spatial climatic characteristics of China. However, in the case of these global datasets, climatic observations in only ~200 sites were used for interpolation across the complex terrain of China, and therefore significant biases occur over much of the country. However, the coarse spatial resolution of the CMA dataset makes it difficult to determine the relationship between climate change and agriculture on a regional scale, and in addition, climate regimes in mountainous areas are not captured with sufficient precision.
research objective: Consequently, the objectives of the present research are (1) optimization of LZU0025 by extending the station data to neighboring countries and (2) assessment of the accuracy of LZU0025 using three approaches: analysis of surface diagnostic statistics to assess the spline interpolation model, analysis of errors by comparing interpolated values to withheld station data, and comparison of LZU0025 with existing datasets.
challenges: A caution should be taken when using LZU0025 precipitation dataset in this region, and it is suggested that the accuracy of LZU0025 precipitation dataset needs to be further checked once local station data on similar mountainous and remote areas are accessible.
methods: In this study, we collected records of monthly temperature at 1153 stations and precipitation at 1202 stations in China and neighboring countries to construct a monthly climate dataset in China with a 0.025° resolution (~2.5 km). The dataset, named LZU0025, was designed by Lanzhou University and used a partial thin plate smoothing method embedded in the ANUSPLIN software. To assess the accuracy of the new updated LZU0025, several published and widely used monthly air temperature and precipitation products were used for comparisons. Thin plate spline interpolation is well-suited for the interpolation of monthly air temperature and precipitation datasets. Besides using surface diagnostic (e.g., RTGCV) to assess the accuracy of interpolation model, residuals from stations withheld from the interpolation were examined. Considering approximate 1/3 of the size of dataset as withheld data, 700 air temperature and precipitation stations were selected by using SELNOT program in the ANUSPLIN package. The Taylor diagram is an effective way of graphically illustrating how closely a set of patterns match observation in a single graph and has been used to assess the performance of atmospheric model simulations.
dataset: We used the monthly air temperature and precipitation dataset from the China ground monthly climate dataset, based on 753 national meteorological stations. Besides the observations in China, the monthly air temperature data on 405 stations and monthly precipitation data on 449 stations from the neighboring countries (such as India, Mongolia, etc.), obtained from the Global Historical Climate Network (GHCN-Monthly Version 3), were also used in this study.
findings: Based on this comprehensive analysis, we conclude that LZU0025 is a reliable dataset. LZU0025, which has a fine resolution, can be used to identify a greater number of climate types, such as tundra and subpolar continental, along the Himalayan Mountain. We anticipate that LZU0025 can be used for the monitoring of regional climate change and precision agriculture modulation under global climate change.

Verification.Question: Does the data collection method for generating the DSM products involve the use of stereoscopic image matching techniques?
Is the accuracy of datasets in the field assessed by comparing the interpolated values to withheld station data?

Disjunctive.Question: Is the primary method for generating DSM data from satellite images based on stereo pair matching, photogrammetry, or LIDAR?
When correcting geographical coordinates in DSM data, is the preferred reference dataset ASTER-DEM, SRTM, or another DEM product?
For evaluating DSM imaging accuracy, should one use cross-entropy, root mean square error, or another metric?

Concept Completion.Question: What methods are used to reduce noise in satellite imagery data collection for mountainous regions?
Who can provide additional ground station data for improving the accuracy of climate datasets in remote areas?
Where is the commonly used air temperature and precipitation data collected from in the construction of climate datasets with fine resolution?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to generate high-resolution DSM data in challenging terrains?
Example.Answer: One method involves using stereo pair matching from satellite imagery, specifically using corrected forward and nadir-looking images, processed with software like ENVI. This method includes noise reduction and information completion using programs developed in IDL, and geographic correction using ground control points to ensure precise geographic coordinates.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in collecting climate data in mountainous regions?
Example.Answer: A challenge is the presence of significant biases in interpolated climatic data due to the coarse spatial resolution of global datasets and limited observation stations, which do not capture the complex climate regimes in mountainous areas with sufficient precision.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a dataset that integrates data from multiple countries to enhance climatic resolution?
Example.Answer: An example is the LZU0025 dataset, which integrates monthly air temperature and precipitation data from 1153 stations in China and 405 stations from neighboring countries, using thin plate spline interpolation to achieve a fine resolution of 0.025°.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key characteristics of a DSM product dataset generated from satellite imagery in mountainous regions?
Feature Specification.Answer: cloud cover, shadow noise, stereo pair matching methods, geographic correction, ground control points, coordinate accuracy, cross-entropy, root mean square error, surface error information entropy

Feature Specification.Question: What are the essential features of a high-resolution climate dataset designed for regional climate change monitoring?
Feature Specification.Answer: fine spatial resolution 0.025° (~2.5 km), data from multiple meteorological stations, sophisticated interpolation methods like partial thin plate smoothing, validated against existing datasets, reliability in identifying climate types

Quantification.Question: How many stations were used to construct the monthly climate dataset with a 0.025° resolution in China and neighboring countries?
What is the resolution of the climate dataset designed for China and neighboring countries?
What is the scale of resolution used to assess the geographic coordinate error in the DSM data collection method?

Definition.Question: What does 'DSM' mean in the context of satellite imagery and how is it generated?
Definition.Answer: DSM stands for Digital Surface Model, which is a representation of the Earth's surface, including all objects on it, such as trees and buildings. It is generated using stereo image pairs from satellite imagery by matching corresponding points to create a 3D representation of the terrain.

Definition.Question: What are the challenges associated with data collection in mountainous regions for climate datasets?
Definition.Answer: The challenges include significant biases in interpolation due to the coarse spatial resolution of global datasets and insufficient precision in capturing climate regimes in mountainous areas. Additionally, the limited access to local station data in remote areas adds complexity to ensuring dataset accuracy.

Comparison.Question: How does the method of using IDL for noise reduction in satellite imagery compare to the use of traditional noise reduction techniques in terms of effectiveness in mountainous regions?
Comparison.Answer: The use of IDL for noise reduction is specifically designed to handle the challenges of multi-cloud mountainous areas, which may provide advantages over traditional noise reduction techniques that might not be tailored for such specific conditions.

Comparison.Question: In what ways does the DSM production process using ENVI differ from the thin plate spline interpolation method used in climatic dataset creation, in terms of data preprocessing and accuracy assessment?
Comparison.Answer: The DSM production process using ENVI involves generating DSM from stereo image pairs with geographic correction, while the thin plate spline interpolation involves constructing a climate dataset with fine resolution using surface diagnostics and withheld data for accuracy assessment. The focus on geographic accuracy in DSM contrasts with the climatic dataset's emphasis on interpolation accuracy.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of satellite imagery and stereoscopic matching techniques enhance the precision of digital surface models in mountainous regions?
Interpretation.Answer: By using stereoscopic matching techniques with satellite imagery, one can generate large-scale DSM data for regions like debris-flow channels. This approach can be enhanced by applying denoising and information completion programs, especially in areas with cloud and shadow noise, ensuring improved imaging precision.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise when using global climatic datasets for regional agricultural productivity studies, and how can these be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: A significant challenge is the coarse spatial resolution of global climatic datasets, which may introduce biases over complex terrains. This can be addressed by constructing higher resolution datasets, using more localized data points, and employing interpolation methods tailored for mountainous and remote areas to improve accuracy.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the evaluation of dataset accuracy be enhanced using both statistical and visualization tools?
Interpretation.Answer: Enhancing dataset accuracy can involve using surface diagnostic statistics to assess interpolation models, comparing interpolated values with withheld station data, and employing visualization tools like Taylor diagrams to graphically illustrate how patterns match observations. These methods provide a comprehensive evaluation of data accuracy.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for specialized denoising and information completion programs in satellite imagery for cloud-covered mountainous regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The presence of a large number of cloud layers and shadow noise in the original satellite imagery necessitates the development of specialized denoising and information completion programs to accurately process images for cloud-covered mountainous regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it necessary to use geographical correction with typical ground control points in creating DSM data from satellite imagery?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Geographical correction using typical ground control points is necessary to ensure the geographical coordinate error is minimized to the order of 1", thereby enhancing the accuracy of the DSM data derived from satellite imagery.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons for using multiple accuracy evaluation indicators when validating the precision of DSM imaging?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Multiple accuracy evaluation indicators such as cross entropy, root mean square error, and surface error information entropy are used to comprehensively compare processed DSM data with raw data, validating the enhanced precision of DSM imaging.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using a thin plate spline interpolation method on the accuracy and resolution of climate datasets in complex terrains?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a thin plate spline interpolation method can significantly enhance the accuracy and resolution of climate datasets in complex terrains, as it allows for a finer spatial resolution and better representation of climate types, which are often not captured with sufficient precision in mountainous areas.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the inclusion of data from neighboring countries affect the accuracy and reliability of climate datasets in regional analysis?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Inclusion of data from neighboring countries can improve the accuracy and reliability of climate datasets in regional analysis by providing a more comprehensive set of observations, which helps in refining the interpolation model and reducing biases, especially in areas with complex terrains.

Causal Consequence.Question: What happens to the imaging precision of DSM products when noise reduction and information completion techniques are applied to satellite imagery?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Applying noise reduction and information completion techniques to satellite imagery can enhance the imaging precision of DSM products, as these methods help mitigate cloud and shadow noise, leading to improved accuracy in the final DSM data output.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of utilizing stereoscopic image pair matching methods in the creation of DSM data for landslide-prone areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to generate large-scale DSM data for landslide-prone areas by using stereoscopic image pair matching methods, which allows for effective processing and analysis of terrain in complex regions such as those with significant cloud cover and shadows.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the rationale behind using cross entropy, root mean square error, and surface deviation entropy as accuracy evaluation metrics for DSM processing?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The rationale is to ensure the processed DSM data's imaging accuracy is improved by using rigorous accuracy evaluation metrics such as cross entropy, root mean square error, and surface deviation entropy, which help in comparing the processed data against raw data, thus validating the enhancements achieved.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in generating a DSM using stereo pair matching techniques for satellite remote sensing imagery in mountainous regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedure involves using stereo pair matching techniques on satellite remote sensing imagery, where the left image is the orthorectified image and the right image is the forward-looking rectified image. ENVI software is used to produce the DSM. The process also includes geographical correction using ASTER-DEM data with a resolution of 30 meters, selecting at least four typical ground control points to ensure geographical coordinate errors are within the order of 1 arcsecond.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can denoising and information completion be conducted on satellite images affected by clouds and shadows using IDL programming?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Denoising and information completion on satellite images can be conducted using IDL programming by developing a program specifically designed for mountainous regions with frequent cloud cover. This program is tailored to handle the noise and fill in missing information in satellite images.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are used to validate and assess the accuracy of a generated DSM against original data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The methodologies used for validating and assessing the accuracy of a generated DSM include comparing it with the original data and using accuracy evaluation indicators such as cross-entropy, root mean square error, and surface error information entropy. These metrics help verify that the processing has improved the imaging accuracy of the DSM.

Enablement.Question: What data processing advancements enable the reduction of noise and enhancement of satellite imagery in regions with high cloud cover?
Enablement.Answer: The use of IDL language for developing a denoising and information completion program specifically tailored for satellite imagery in cloud-covered mountainous regions enables the reduction of noise and enhancement of imagery.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of multiple satellite data sources and control points enable more precise geographic calibration in digital surface models (DSM)?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of ASTER-DEM data and the selection of at least four typical ground control points for geographic correction enable precise geographic calibration, ensuring that the geographic coordinate error is minimized to the order of 1″.

Enablement.Question: What methods enable the assessment and validation of the accuracy of climate datasets in complex terrains?
Enablement.Answer: The use of thin plate spline interpolation and a comprehensive analysis involving surface diagnostic statistics, error comparison with withheld station data, and validation against existing datasets enable the assessment and validation of the accuracy of climate datasets, even in complex terrains.

Expectation.Question: Why might traditional interpolation methods lead to significant biases in climate datasets over complex terrains?
Expectation.Answer: Climatic observations in only a limited number of sites are used for interpolation across complex terrains like those in China, leading to significant biases over much of the country.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected challenges when using satellite imagery for DSM production in cloudy mountainous regions?
Expectation.Answer: The presence of large amounts of cloud and shadow noise in original satellite imagery necessitates the development of specialized denoising and information completion programs to improve DSM production accuracy in cloudy mountainous regions.

Expectation.Question: What are the anticipated benefits of extending station data to neighboring countries when constructing high-resolution climate datasets?
Expectation.Answer: By extending station data to neighboring countries, a more comprehensive and reliable climate dataset can be constructed, capturing a greater number of climate types and improving accuracy in mountainous areas.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how significant are the challenges associated with interpolating climate data across complex terrains like China, and what strategies might improve accuracy?
Judgmental.Answer: The challenges are significant due to the coarse resolution of global datasets and sparse climatic observations over complex terrains. Extending station data to neighboring countries and using fine-resolution interpolation methods like partial thin plate smoothing can enhance accuracy, as demonstrated by LZU0025. However, further validation with local datasets in similar remote areas remains crucial.

Judgmental.Question: What is your assessment of the potential of fine-resolution datasets, such as those with 0.025° resolution, in capturing diverse climate types and supporting precision agriculture?
Judgmental.Answer: Fine-resolution datasets hold great potential in capturing diverse climate types, especially in topographically varied regions like the Himalayas. They enable more precise climate monitoring and agricultural planning, aiding in adaptation to climate change. The reliability of such datasets, as shown by LZU0025's ability to identify specific climate types, supports their use in precision agriculture.

Assertion.Question: I can't figure out how data collection techniques can be optimized to improve the accuracy of digital surface models in regions with significant cloud cover and shadows.
Assertion.Answer: A dataset discussed utilizes IDL language to develop a denoising and information completion program specifically for satellite imagery in cloudy mountainous regions, ensuring better accuracy in DSM creation.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the accuracy of a climate dataset can be ensured when interpolating data from a limited number of observation sites across a vast and varied terrain.
Assertion.Answer: One approach is using thin plate spline interpolation with surface diagnostic statistics to assess accuracy, alongside comparing interpolated values to withheld station data and existing datasets to validate the new dataset's reliability.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the methods used to cross-check the precision of geographic coordinate systems in remote sensing data.
Assertion.Answer: To ensure precise geographic coordinates, a dataset uses 30 m resolution ASTER-DEM data with at least four typical ground control points for geographic correction, achieving coordinate errors within an order of magnitude of 1".

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data processing techniques used for generating digital surface models in regions with cloud and shadow noise, focusing on methodologies for noise reduction and information completion.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data processing techniques involve developing a denoising and information completion program using the IDL language, specifically tailored for satellite imagery in mountainous areas with frequent cloud cover. This program addresses the noise issues caused by clouds and shadows in the original satellite images.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges in ensuring geographic accuracy when using multiple data sources for DSM production and suggest methods for geographic correction.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges include ensuring accurate geographic alignment and minimizing coordinate errors when integrating various data sources. Methods for geographic correction include using at least four typical ground control points for geographic calibration with 30 m resolution ASTER-DEM data to ensure geographic coordinate errors are reduced to the order of 1″.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential strategies for evaluating the precision of DSM products in remote and mountainous areas, including the use of accuracy assessment indicators.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential strategies for evaluating precision include using cross-entropy, root mean square error, and surface error information entropy as accuracy assessment indicators. These indicators are used to compare the processed DSM against the original data to verify improvements in imaging precision.
